description:
Add a static method to get supported container format from MediaCodec

This will enable us to query the canPlayType for EME

BUG=224793

Committed: https://src.chromium.org/viewvc/chrome?view=rev&revision=222738

messages.text:
https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/3001/media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java
File media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java (right):

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/3001/media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java#newcode80
media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java:80: private static class ContainerCodecPair {
Add documentation w/ examples for easier understanding. Also, in the native side, we use Codec's' sometimes. I like it with 's' more since it's more clear. At least we should be consistent.

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/3001/media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java#newcode134
media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java:134: private static ContainerCodecPair[] getContainerCodecPairs() {
Add comment about what this function is expected to do? Without the context of ddorwin's CL, it's hard to understand what we are doing here.

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/3001/media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java#newcode147
media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java:147: MediaCodec secureCodec = MediaCodec.createByCodecName(secureCodecName);
So we don't care about the L3 decoders? If we care, then it seems we can reuse the logic on line 200.

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/3001/media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java#newcode156
media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java:156: containerCodecMap.put(supportedTypes[j], existingCodecs + "," + codecString);
Will containerCodecMap.get() work if the key is not in the map? If so we can always call:

String existingCodecs = containerCodecMap.get(supportedTypes[j]);
containerCodecMap.put(supportedTypes[j], existingCodecs + ",
                      " + codecString);

and drop the "else" block on line 158. If supportedTypes[j] is not in the map, existingCodecs will be empty, so this code should still work.

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/3001/media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java#newcode167
media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java:167: return containerCodecList.toArray(new ContainerCodecPair[containerCodecList.size()]);
Newbie question: Is ArrayList and toArray the only way we can pass a list to the native side? It seems that this can be wrapped into a static function.

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/3001/media/base/android/media_codec_bridge.cc
File media/base/android/media_codec_bridge.cc (right):

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/3001/media/base/android/media_codec_bridge.cc#newcode104
media/base/android/media_codec_bridge.cc:104: ContainerCodecsPair(container_type, codecs));
Oh my, I hate JNI :)

media/base/android/media_codec_bridge.cc:108: 
remove one extra empty line

add include for std::pair

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/3001/media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java#newcode147
media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java:147: MediaCodec secureCodec = MediaCodec.createByCodecName(secureCodecName);
All the codecs returned by MediaCodecList should support L3, so we don't need to instantiate them.

On 2013/09/10 00:30:20, xhwang wrote:
> So we don't care about the L3 decoders? If we care, then it seems we can reuse
> the logic on line 200.

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/3001/media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java#newcode156
media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java:156: containerCodecMap.put(supportedTypes[j], existingCodecs + "," + codecString);
This will add an extra "," at the beginning of the string. The if-else statement is trying to avoid that.

On 2013/09/10 00:30:20, xhwang wrote:
> Will containerCodecMap.get() work if the key is not in the map? If so we can
> always call:
> 
> String existingCodecs = containerCodecMap.get(supportedTypes[j]);
> containerCodecMap.put(supportedTypes[j], existingCodecs + ",
>                       " + codecString);
> 
> and drop the "else" block on line 158. If supportedTypes[j] is not in the map,
> existingCodecs will be empty, so this code should still work.

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/3001/media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java#newcode167
media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java:167: return containerCodecList.toArray(new ContainerCodecPair[containerCodecList.size()]);
All container types(ArrayList, Hashmap， etc) is a java object, so native side don't have a way to read the individual element. To parse a container object, native need to call jni function to first get the size of the java container object, and then use jni calls to get each element of it. Array, on the other hand, let the native side to access each elemen.
The function is pretty short, and the code is not being reused by others. I would rather leave it in the current state.


On 2013/09/10 00:30:20, xhwang wrote:
> Newbie question: Is ArrayList and toArray the only way we can pass a list to the
> native side? It seems that this can be wrapped into a static function.

media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java:156: containerCodecMap.put(supportedTypes[j], existingCodecs + "," + codecString);
On 2013/09/10 02:49:12, qinmin wrote:
> This will add an extra "," at the beginning of the string. The if-else statement
> is trying to avoid that.
> 
> On 2013/09/10 00:30:20, xhwang wrote:
> > Will containerCodecMap.get() work if the key is not in the map? If so we can
> > always call:
> > 
> > String existingCodecs = containerCodecMap.get(supportedTypes[j]);
> > containerCodecMap.put(supportedTypes[j], existingCodecs + ",
> >                       " + codecString);
> > 
> > and drop the "else" block on line 158. If supportedTypes[j] is not in the map,
> > existingCodecs will be empty, so this code should still work.
> 

Hmm, can we always append the "," after the codec name? e.g.

String existingCodecs = containerCodecMap.get(supportedTypes[j]);
containerCodecMap.put(supportedTypes[j], existingCodecs + codecString + ",");

Then when we copy the list into the array, we always strip the last char?

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/9001/media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java
File media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java (right):

media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java:83: * "OMX.google.aac.decoder".
hmm, native code won't understand what "OMX.google.aac.decoder" is. So we have to translate this into something like "aac" or "mp4a" at some point. If we have to do the translation later, does it make sense to keep a list of codec names instead of searializing it into a comma separated string, which we have to parse again later for translation?

More comments; mostly on container/codec confusion.

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/17001/media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java
File media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java (right):

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/17001/media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java#newcode177
media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java:177: getCodecsFromMediaCodecInfo(supportedTypes[j]),
I am confused here, we are supposed to get a container-codec pair list. But it seems supportedTypes[j] is also a codec type (based on the list on 192. 

Actually MediaCodec doesn't care about container type (e.g. mp4 or webm). Only Demuxer and MediaDrm cares about container. Demuxer needs to know the container type to be able to parse it correctly. MediaDrm needs to support the initdata which is container type specific. So in our case, it seems that container type and codec type are orthogonal: we can get a list of codec separately and then just multiply it with the container type we support.

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/17001/media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java#newcode191
media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java:191: private static String getCodecsFromMediaCodecInfo(String containerType) {
s/containerType/codecType/

avc, vorbis etc are all codec names.

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/17001/media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java#newcode191
media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java:191: private static String getCodecsFromMediaCodecInfo(String containerType) {
This function is kind of the reverse of https://code.google.com/p/chromium/codesearch#chromium/src/media/base/android/media_codec_bridge.cc&sq=package:chromium&l=55

It'll be nice to have both functions in the same layer (native or java), and have a static map that we can use to do the conversion. But that can be done in a separate CL.

And added 2 calls in native to map mime to container type and codecs.

> and codec type are orthogonal: we can get a list of codec separately and then

Can we try to avoid the word "mime"? It's kind of confusing. How about SupportedCodecInfo or just CodecInfo?

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/4004/media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java#newcode142
media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java:142: new HashMap<String, CodecMimeInfo>();
hmm, can we just have a map <codec_type, secure_decoder_supported> ?

I am not sure why we need a map like:
<codec_type, pair<codec_type, secure_decoder_supported> > ...

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/4004/media/base/android/media_codec_bridge.h
File media/base/android/media_codec_bridge.h (right):

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/4004/media/base/android/media_codec_bridge.h#newcode55
media/base/android/media_codec_bridge.h:55: std::string container_type;
Hmm, I see why you have the map in the java code. But really the first element is still a codec type. MediaCodec knows nothing about the container type. We need MediaSourcePlayer or something else to combine container and codec info and make the final ContainerCodecsInfo.

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/4004/media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java
File media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java (right):

On 2013/09/11 18:16:00, xhwang wrote:
> Can we try to avoid the word "mime"? It's kind of confusing. How about
> SupportedCodecInfo or just CodecInfo?

Done.

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/4004/media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java#newcode142
media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java:142: new HashMap<String, CodecMimeInfo>();
This is to facilitate the output of the Array.
If we use <codec_type, secure_decoder_supported>, the we need an extra loop to create an array, and insert each item from the map to the array.
use <codec_type, pair<codec_type, secure_decoder_supported> >, we can simply call Hashmap.values().toArray() to convert the output to an array. The code is much cleaner than the former

On 2013/09/11 18:16:00, xhwang wrote:
> hmm, can we just have a map <codec_type, secure_decoder_supported> ?
>

> <codec_type, pair<codec_type, secure_decoder_supported> > ...

Yes, that's why i added 2 static functions in the C++ file to convert codec type to container type and codecs.
So the final ContainerCodecsInfo will be something like {"video/webm","vp8", false}

> create an array, and insert each item from the map to the array.
> use <codec_type, pair<codec_type, secure_decoder_supported> >, we can simply
> call Hashmap.values().toArray() to convert the output to an array. The code is
> much cleaner than the former
> 
> On 2013/09/11 18:16:00, xhwang wrote:
> > hmm, can we just have a map <codec_type, secure_decoder_supported> ?
> > 
> > I am not sure why we need a map like:
> > <codec_type, pair<codec_type, secure_decoder_supported> > ...

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/24001/media/base/android/media_codec_bridge.cc
File media/base/android/media_codec_bridge.cc (right):

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/24001/media/base/android/media_codec_bridge.cc#newcode70
media/base/android/media_codec_bridge.cc:70: static const std::string MimeTypeToCodecType(const std::string& mime) {
s/MimeType/AndroidCodecType or AndroidMimeType

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/24001/media/base/android/media_codec_bridge.cc#newcode106
media/base/android/media_codec_bridge.cc:106: }
Container and codec should be relatively orthogonal. Nothing prevents people from putting vp8 into a .mp4 container. This list is fine for our use cases, but I really think we should not have anything related to container in MediaCodec* classes. Maybe move this conversion to MediaSourcePlayer?

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/24001/media/base/android/media_codec_bridge.h
File media/base/android/media_codec_bridge.h (right):

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/24001/media/base/android/media_codec_bridge.h#newcode58
media/base/android/media_codec_bridge.h:58: };
This list is is intermediate result and we have to combine it with container type, key_system, security level etc to create a KeySystemInfo list. So I'd keep it concise and short. How about dropping |container_type| here and handles containers in a higher level (e.g. in MediaSourcePlayer)?

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/4004/media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java
File media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java (right):

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/4004/media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java#newcode142
media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java:142: new HashMap<String, CodecMimeInfo>();
There are several problems:
1. vector.indexOf() is inefficient compared to map
2. we need to implement the equals() function for CodecMimeInfo as it is not a primitive type as string
3. "video/vp8, true" and "video/vp8, false" will be separate entries if we use vector.indexOf(), but we only need to return 1 entry since the former implies the latter

On 2013/09/11 21:01:23, xhwang wrote:
> I am not familiar with Java. But why we can't use
> Vector<CodecMimeInfo>.toArray()?
>

> > use <codec_type, pair<codec_type, secure_decoder_supported> >, we can simply

fit in one line?

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/4004/media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java
File media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java (right):

https://codereview.chromium.org/23549021/diff/4004/media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java#newcode142
media/base/android/java/src/org/chromium/media/MediaCodecBridge.java:142: new HashMap<String, CodecMimeInfo>();
EntrySet is a generic type, and generic array creation is not allowed in Java. So I need to return an object[] from this function. 
Then when the native side ask java to return the value of the entry inside the object array, java side needs to convert the object to an EntrySet.
In this case, the CodecMimeInfo class is no longer needed. All we need is EntrySet<String, Boolean> and object[]. But the code then becomes hard to read. There are wierd java functions that tries to parse an jobject.
